TEXT.English: [TAB]Edible salt is a mineral, one of the few rocks humans eat. Salt is necessary for the survival of all living creatures, including humans. Salt is involved in regulating the water content (fluid balance) of the body. Salt flavor is one of the basic tastes. In the past, salt was difficult to obtain, but had a great importance in food preservation and as a vital food additive. Therefore, it was a highly valued trade item throughout history. Wars were fought over it; states were formed and destroyed because of it. Roman soldiers were partially paid with salt, and this is still evident in the English language as the word salary derives from the Latin word salarium that means payment in salt (Latin sal), as well as the phrase "worth one's salt". It was also of high value to the Hebrews, Greeks and other peoples of antiquity. During the late Roman Empire and throughout the Middle Ages salt was a precious commodity carried along the salt roads into the heartland of the Germanic tribes. Cities, states and dukedoms along the salt roads exacted heavy duties and taxes for the salt passing through their territories. This practice caused wars, it even caused the formation of cities such as the city of Munich in 1158 when the then Duke of Bavaria Henry XII, called The Lion, decided that the bishops of Freising no longer needed their salt revenue.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le sel de table ou sel alimentaire ou sel de cuisine, composé essentiellement de chlorure de sodium, se présente sous différentes formes : sel fin, gros sel, fleur de sel. En cuisine il permet d'assaisonner les plats. Les Italiens préfèrent le gros sel avec lequel ils relèvent leurs pâtes ; les Belges utilisent plus volontiers le sel fin emballé dans des sachets. Le sel, d'origine marine, peut être extrait de la mer ou des gisements fossiles. Le sel marin est récolté (cueilli) dans des marais salants, comme à Guérande ou à Salin-de-Giraud. Le sel fossile ou sel gemme est extrait des mines de sel, comme à Bex ou à Varangéville. Le raffinage permet d'obtenir un sel de la couleur blanche préférée par le consommateur, composé de NaCl pratiquement pur (99,9%), ceci, au détriment de ses qualités alimentaires. Des adjuvants, tels des anti-agglomérants ou des composés fluorés ou iodés peuvent se retrouver dans le sel raffiné. Il permet aussi la conservation des aliments. Au Moyen Âge, c'était le principal moyen de conserver les viandes et poissons et de survivre ainsi aux disettes. Aujourd'hui encore, certaines régions africaines dépourvues d'appareils frigorifiques, utilisent le sel pour conserver viandes et poissons, tout comme les consommateurs des pays dits développés trouvent dans le commerce des produits salés : navet salé, hareng saur, morue, etc. Le même sel raffiné est aussi utilisé pour assurer le fonctionnement (régénération en ions positifs) des adoucisseurs d'eau présents dans les lave-vaisselles. On parle alors de « sel régénérant ».
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die wichtige Bedeutung der Salzaufnahme für den Organismus ist daran zu erkennen, dass es einen eigenen Geschmackssinn "salzig" gibt und Salz schon immer zu den begehrtesten Gewürzen gehörte. Außer zur individuellen Würzung ist Speisesalz bei der Herstellung von Fleisch- und Wurstwaren, Brot und Käse unentbehrlich. Es war lange Zeit ein sehr wertvolles Handelsgut, das bereits in vorgeschichtlicher Zeit auf so genannten Salzstraßen von den Herstellungsorten in salzarme Regionen exportiert wurde. Aus Salzstraßen wurden später bedeutende Handelsstraßen. Der Salzhandel war in Deutschland bis 1993 mit der Salzsteuer belegt. Der Handel mit Salz war ein wichtiges Monopol. Städte, die das Salzregal besaßen, wachten sehr aufmerksam darüber, dass innerhalb dessen Geltungsbereiches kein anderer Salzhandel stattfand. Eine weit verbreitete, bereits seit dem Altertum bekannte Methode ist dabei das Ausfällen von Salz durch verschiedene Verdunstungsarten aus salzhaltigen Lösungen. Durch das Auswaschen und Filtrieren salziger Erde und anschließende Einkochen wurde in Südamerika ebenfalls Salz gewonnen. An verschiedenen Salzlagerstätten Europas wurde die Methode des Siedens einer durch Ausspülung gewonnen Salzlösung bereits in der Jungsteinzeit praktiziert. Bis heute wird in Westafrika in der Umgebung des Tschadsees, in Guatemala, in Thailand und in Neuguinea auf diese Weise Salz hergestellt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A greenish mineral, Jade is extremely hard and robust, and has been in use for many thousands of years. Jade was originally used in tools and weapons, but as other more effective substances (like bronze and iron) were discovered, jade would become used largely for ornamental purposes. Jade was first widely used in China during the Neolithic period. Over time as the most accessible sources were depleted, it became more valuable than gold. Today jade is still used in jewellery and in a variety of trinkets, though it no longer carries the prestige or value it once did.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Minéral verdâtre, le jade est extrêmement dur et résistant, et utilisé depuis des milliers d'années. On s'en sert initialement pour les outils et les armes, mais à mesure que d'autres matériaux sont découverts, comme le bronze et le fer, le jade est de plus en plus utilisé comme ornement. Le jade est largement utilisé en Chine pendant le néolithique. Avec le temps et l'épuisement des sources principales, il devient plus rare que l'or. De nos jours, le jade est encore utilisé en bijouterie et pour divers bibelots, même s'il n'a plus son prestige et sa valeur d'antan.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein grünliches Mineral, Jade ist extrem hart und robust und ist im Gebrauch für viele Tausenden Jahre gewesen. Jade wurde ursprünglich in den Werkzeugen und in den Waffen benutzt, aber, während andere wirkungsvollere Substanzen (wie Bronze und Eisen) entdeckt wurden, würde Jade groß für dekorative Zwecke verwendet werden. Jade war erste allgemein verwendet in China während der neolithischen Periode. Überzeit als die zugänglichsten Quellen wurden verbraucht, es wurde wertvoller als Gold. Heute wird Jade noch in den Schmucksachen benutzt und in einer Vielzahl von Trinkets, obwohl es nicht mehr das Prestige trägt oder bewertet, sie einmal.

TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un mineral verdoso, jade es extremadamente duro y robusto, y ha estado en el uso para muchos millares de años. El jade fue utilizado originalmente en herramientas y armas, pero como otras sustancias más eficaces (como el bronce y el hierro) fueron descubiertas, el jade se utilizaría en gran parte para los propósitos ornamentales. El jade era primer usado extensamente en China durante el período neolítico. En un cierto plazo como las fuentes más accesibles fue agotada, él llegó a ser más valioso que el oro. El jade todavía se utiliza hoy en joyería y en una variedad de baratijas, aunque lleva el prestigio o lo valora no más de largo una vez.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In its native Central America and South America, rubber has been collected for a long time. The Mesoamerican civilizations used rubber mostly from Castilla elastica. The Ancient Mesoamericans had a ball game using rubber balls, and a few Pre-Columbian rubber balls have been found (always in sites that were flooded under fresh water), the earliest dating to about 1600 BC. According to Bernal Díaz del Castillo, the Spanish Conquistadores were so astounded by the vigorous bouncing of the rubber balls of the Aztecs that they wondered if the balls were enchanted by evil spirits. The Maya also made a type of temporary rubber shoe by dipping their feet into a latex mixture. Rubber was used in various other contexts, such as strips to hold stone and metal tools to wooden handles, and padding for the tool handles. While the ancient Mesoamericans did not have vulcanization, they developed organic methods of processing the rubber with similar results, mixing the raw latex with various saps and juices of other vines, particularly Ipomoea alba, a species of Morning glory. In Brazil, the natives understood the use of rubber to make water-resistant cloth. A story says that the first European to return to Portugal from Brazil with samples of such water-repellent rubberised cloth so shocked people that he was brought to court on the charge of witchcraft.[PARAGRAPH:1]When samples of rubber first arrived in England, it was observed by Joseph Priestley, in 1770, that a piece of the material was extremely good for rubbing out pencil marks on paper.[PARAGRAPH:1]The para rubber tree initially grew in South America, where it was the main source of what limited amount of latex rubber was consumed during much of the 19th century. About 100 years ago, the Congo Free State in Africa was a significant source of natural rubber latex, mostly gathered by forced labor. The Congo Free State was forged and ruled as a personal colony by the Belgian King Leopold II where millions of Africans died as a result of lust for rubber and rubber profits. After repeated efforts rubber was successfully cultivated in Southeast Asia, where it is now widely grown.
TEXT.French: [TAB]En Amérique Centrale et en Amérique du Sud, le caoutchouc a été rassemblé pendant longtemps par les indigènes. TODO Les civilisations de Mesoamerican ont employé le caoutchouc la plupart du temps de l'elastica de la Castille. Le Mesoamericans antique a eu un jeu de boule en utilisant les boules en caoutchouc, et quelques boules en caoutchouc Pré-Colombiennes ont été trouvées (toujours dans les emplacements qui ont été inondés sous l'eau doux), le plus tôt datant environ à 1600 AVANT JÉSUS CHRIST. Selon Bernal Díaz del Castillo, le Conquistadores espagnol étaient ainsi étonné par le rebondissement vigoureux des boules en caoutchouc de l'Aztecs qu'ils se sont demandés si les boules étaient enchantées par des spiritueux mauvais. Le Maya a également fait un type de la chaussure en caoutchouc provisoire en plongeant leurs pieds dans un mélange de latex. Le caoutchouc a été employé dans de divers autres contextes, tels que des bandes pour tenir des outils de pierre et en métal sur les poignées en bois, et la remplissage pour les poignées d'outil. Tandis que le Mesoamericans antique n'avait pas la vulcanisation, elles ont développé des méthodes organiques de traiter le caoutchouc avec les résultats semblables, mélangeant le latex cru à de divers sèves et jus d'autres vignes, en particulier Ipomoea alba, des espèces de gloire de matin. Au Brésil les indigènes ont compris l'utilisation du caoutchouc de faire le tissu résistant à l'eau. Une histoire indique que le premier Européen à retourner au Portugal du Brésil avec des échantillons d'un tel tissu caoutchouté hydrofuge a ainsi choqué les personnes qu'il a été apportées à la cour sur la charge des échantillons de witchcraft.[PARAGRAPH:1]When du caoutchouc est arrivé la première fois en Angleterre, il a été observé par Joseph Priestley, en 1770, qu'un morceau du matériel était extrêmement bon pour frotter hors des marques de crayon sur l'arbre en caoutchouc de paper.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Para. s'est au commencement développé en Amérique Du sud, où c'était la source principale de quelle quantité limitée du caoutchouc de latex a été consommé pendant le une grande partie du 19ème siècle. Il y a environ 100 ans, l'état libre du Congo en Afrique était une source significative de latex normal, la plupart du temps recueillie par le travail obligatoire. L'état libre du Congo a été forgé et a régné en tant que colonie personnelle par le Roi belge Leopold II où des millions d'Africains morts en raison de la convoitise pour le caoutchouc et des bénéfices en caoutchouc. Après que répété le caoutchouc d'efforts a été avec succès cultivé en Asie du Sud-Est, où il est maintenant largement développé.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kautschuk (auch Gummi elasticum oder Resina elastica) ist ein gummiartiger Stoff im Milchsaft verschiedener Pflanzen. Bei diesem handelt sich meist wirklich um eine milchige Flüssigkeit, er tritt aber in manchen Pflanzen auch in halbfester Form auf. Der Milchsaft schmeckt angenehm und ist genießbar. Wirtschaftlich am bedeutsamsten für die Kautschukgewinnung ist der aus Südamerika stammende Kautschukbaum (Hevea brasiliensis) aus der Familie der Wolfsmilchgewächse.[NEWLINE]Ursprünglich war der Kautschukbaum nur im Amazonasbecken heimisch, sein Name wurde aus der Sprache der Ureinwohner übernommen und bedeutet in etwa "weinendes Holz". Die ältesten Gegenstände aus Kautschuk sind aus der Zeit um 1600 v. Chr bekannt. Die Völker des mittelamerikanischen Mesoamerikas und die indigenen Völker Amazoniens nutzten ihn schon lange vor Eintreffen der Europäer für die Herstellung von Schläuchen, Gefäßen, Vollgummibällen für ihre berühmten Ballspiele, aber auch für Fackeln und sogar Kleidungsstücke. Der Kautschuk blieb auch nach der Entdeckung Amerikas in Europa lange Zeit weitgehend unbekannt. Erst 1735 bis 1745 untersuchte eine Expedition der Pariser Akademie der Wissenschaft im Amazonasgebiet die Verwendung und Verarbeitung des Kautschuks genauer. Nach einer Vielzahl von Versuchen mit dem neuen Werkstoff wurden Lösungsmittel für festen Kautschuk gefunden und Verfahren entwickelt, mit denen sich der gelöste Stoff auf Gewebe auftragen ließ. Die Herstellung der ersten Radiergummis, Regenmäntel und Gummistiefel war damit zwar schon möglich, einen richtigen Kautschukboom löste aber erst die Erfindung der Vulkanisation 1839 durch den Amerikaner Charles Goodyear aus.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In relativi America Centrale e Sudamerica natali, la gomma è stata raccolta a lungo. Le civilizzazioni di Mesoamerican hanno usato la gomma principalmente dal elastica della Castiglia. Il Mesoamericans antico ha avuto un gioco della sfera usando le sfere di gomma ed alcune sfere di gomma Pre-Colombiane sono state trovate (sempre in luoghi che sono stati sommersi sotto acqua dolce), il più in anticipo che data BC a circa 1600. Secondo Bernal Díaz del Castillo, il Conquistadores spagnolo era in modo da sbalordito dal rimbalzo vigoroso delle sfere di gomma del Aztecs che si sono domandati se le sfere fossero incantate dagli alcoolici diabolici. Il maya inoltre ha fatto un tipo del pattino di gomma provvisorio tuffando i loro piedi in una miscela del lattice. La gomma è stata usata nei vari contesti, quali le strisce per tenere gli attrezzi del metallo e della pietra alle maniglie di legno ed al riempimento per le maniglie dell'attrezzo. Mentre il Mesoamericans antico non ha avuto vulcanizzazione, hanno messo a punto i metodi organici di elaborazione della gomma con risultati simili, mescolanti il lattice grezzo con vario fiaccano e spremute di altre viti, specialmente Ipomoea alba, una specie di glory di mattina. Nel Brasile i nativi hanno capito l'uso di gomma fare il panno resistente all'acqua. Una storia dice che il primo europeo da rinviare nel Portogallo dal Brasile con i campioni di tale panno gommato idrorepellente così ha scosso la gente che è stato portato alla corte sulla carica dei campioni di witchcraft.[PARAGRAPH:1]When di gomma in primo luogo è arrivato in Inghilterra, esso è stato osservato da Joseph Priestley, in 1770, che una parte del materiale era estremamente buona per la lucidatura verso l'esterno i contrassegni della matita sull'albero della gomma di paper.[PARAGRAPH:1]The paragrafi inizialmente si è sviluppata nel Sudamerica, in cui era la fonte principale di che quantità limitata di gomma del lattice è stato consumato durante il gran parte del diciannovesimo secolo. Circa 100 anni fa, il Congo libero Dichiara in Africa era una fonte significativa di latice di gomma naturale, principalmente riunita dal lavoro forzato. Il Congo libero Dichiara è stato forgiato e regolato come colonia personale dal re belga Leopold II dove milioni di Africani sono morto come conseguenza di lust per gomma ed i profitti della gomma. Dopo che ripetuto la gomma di sforzi si coltivi con successo in Asia sudorientale, in cui ora ampiamente si sviluppa.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]En su America Central y Suramérica nativas, el caucho se ha recogido durante mucho tiempo. Las civilizaciones de Mesoamerican utilizaron el caucho sobre todo del elastica de Castilla. El Mesoamericans antiguo tenía un juego de la bola usando las bolas de goma, y se han encontrado algunas bolas de goma Pre-Colombinas (siempre en los sitios que fueron inundados debajo del agua dulce), el más temprano que fechaba a cerca de 1600 A.C.. Según Bernal Díaz del Castillo, el Conquistadores español estaba así que asombrado por despedir vigoroso de las bolas de goma del Aztecs que se preguntaban si las bolas fueron encantadas por alcoholes malvados. El maya también hizo un tipo del zapato de goma temporal sumergiendo sus pies en una mezcla del látex. El caucho fue utilizado en contextos otros, tales como tiras para sostener las herramientas de la piedra y del metal a las manijas de madera, y al acolchado para las manijas de la herramienta. Mientras que el Mesoamericans antiguo no tenía vulcanización, desarrollaron los métodos orgánicos de procesar el caucho con resultados similares, mezclando el látex crudo con las varios savias y jugos de otras vides, particularmente Ipomoea alba, una especie de la gloria de mañana. En el Brasil los naturales entendían el uso del caucho de hacer el paño hidrófugo. Una historia dice que el primer europeo a volver a Portugal del Brasil con las muestras de tal paño recubierto de goma impermeable dio una sacudida eléctrica tan a gente a que le trajeron a la corte en la carga de muestras de witchcraft.[PARAGRAPH:1]When del caucho primero llegó en Inglaterra, él fue observado por José Priestley, en 1770, que un pedazo del material era extremadamente bueno para frotar fuera de marcas del lápiz en árbol del caucho de paper.[PARAGRAPH:1]The párrafos creció inicialmente en Suramérica, donde estaba la fuente principal de qué cantidad limitada de caucho del látex fue consumido durante mucho del diecinueveavo siglo. Hace aproximadamente 100 años, el estado libre de Congo en África era una fuente significativa del látex de caucho natural, recolectada sobre todo por el trabajo forzado. El estado libre de Congo fue forjado y gobernó como colonia personal del rey belga Leopold II donde millones de africanos murieron como resultado de la lujuria para el caucho y los beneficios del caucho. Después de que estuvo repetido el caucho de los esfuerzos fuera cultivado con éxito en Asia suroriental, en donde ahora se crece extensamente.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The opium poppy (Papaver somniferum) is the type of poppy from which opium and all other refined opiates such as morphine can be extracted. The opium poppy probably originated in the eastern Mediterranean area and was subsequently spread to its modern range which covers much of southern Asia and beyond. Opium was used in the ancient Mediterranean for its medicinal qualities and as recreational narcotic. The use of the opium poppy most likely predates written history, but the first known historical occurrences of opium poppies are images found in ancient Sumerian artefacts dating to approximately 4000 B.C. Use of the opium poppy spread and by the 5th century B.C. was also known to the Greeks, who gave opium its current name.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Opium ist ein Rausch-, Betäubungs- und Arzneimittel, das aus dem Milchsaft des Schlafmohns (Papaver somniferum L.) gewonnen wird. Seine Wirkung beruht hauptsächlich auf den Alkaloiden Morphin, Codein und Thebain.[NEWLINE]Mohn gehört zu den ältesten Kulturpflanzen. Bereits um 4000 v. Chr. wurde er zur Herstellung von Pharmazeutika verwendet. In Ägypten wurden Opiummixturen ab etwa 1800 v. Chr. für Kulthandlungen verwendet. Das Opium wurde zunächst von Zypern importiert und später im Niltal angebaut. Auch im alten Griechenland wurd Opium für kultische und medizinische Zwecke gebraucht. Die Mohnkapsel war das Symbol für den Schlafgott Hypnos, für Morpheus, den Gott des Traumes, für Nyx, die Göttin der Nacht, und für Thanatos, den Gott des Todes. Im römischen Reich wurde Opium zur Wohlstandsdroge. Im frühen Christentum wurde die Anwendung von Opium als schmerzstillendes Mittel vielerorts verboten und erst mit der arabischen Medizin kehrte es schließlich nach Europa zurück.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'oppio è una sostanza ottenuta incidendo le capsule del Papaver somniferum e raccogliendone la linfa che trasuda, che poi viene lasciata rapprendere all'aria in una resina scura ed impastata in pani di color brunastro, che emanano un odore dolciastro ed hanno un sapore amaro. Si usa molto nelle culture orientali e mediorientali, sia per usi terapeutici sia per scopi rituali e ricreativi. Sono state ritrovate capsule di Papaver somniferum addirittura negli scavi di palafitte dell'uomo di Cro-Magnon. I Sumeri di 5.000 anni ne tramandarono l'uso alle successive civiltà caldea e assiro-babilonese: questi ne introdussero l'uso in Egitto verso il 1500 AC. Un antico papiro egiziano raccomanda l'uso del papavero da oppio come sedativo. Ippocrate, nel IV secolo AC, consigliava l'oppio come rimedio per numerosi mali, mentre l'oppio fece il suo ingresso nella civiltà romana quando questa conquistò la Grecia.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) is a palm in the genus Phoenix, cultivated for its edible sweet fruit. Although its place of origin is unknown because of long cultivation, it probably originated from lands around the Persian Gulf. It is a medium-sized plant, 15 - 25 m tall, growing singly or forming a clump with several stems from a single root system. The leaves are 3 - 5 m long, with spines on the petiole, and pinnate, with about 150 leaflets; the leaflets are 30 cm long and 2 cm wide. The full span of the crown ranges from 6 to 10 m.

[TAB]Citrus is a genus of flowering trees and shrubs in the rue family, Rutaceae. Plants in the genus produce citrus fruits, including important crops such as oranges, lemons, grapefruits, pomelos, and limes. The genus Citrus is native to South Asia, East Asia, Southeast Asia, Melanesia, and Australia. Various citrus species have been utilized and domesticated by indigenous cultures in these areas since ancient times. From there its cultivation spread into Micronesia and Polynesia by the Austronesian expansion (c. 3000–1500 BCE); and to the Middle East and the Mediterranean (c. 1200 BCE) via the incense trade route, and onwards to Europe.

[TAB]Obsidian is a naturally occurring glass formed as an extrusive igneous rock. It is produced when felsic lava extruded from a volcano cools without crystal growth. Obsidian is commonly found within the margins of rhyolitic lava flows known as obsidian flows, where the chemical composition (high silica content) induces a high viscosity and polymerisation degree of the lava. The inhibition of atomic diffusion through this highly viscous and polymerized lava explains the lack of crystal growth. Because of the lack of crystal structure, obsidian blade edges can reach almost molecular thinness, leading to its ancient use as projectile points, and its modern use as surgical scalpel blades.[PARAGRAPH:2]Obsidian is mineral-like, but not a true mineral because as a glass it is not crystalline; in addition, its composition is too complex to comprise a single mineral. It is sometimes classified as a mineraloid. Though obsidian is dark in color similar to mafic rocks such as basalt, obsidian's composition is extremely felsic. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pure obsidian is usually dark in appearance, though the color varies depending on the presence of impurities. Iron and magnesium typically give the obsidian a dark green to brown to black color. A very few samples are nearly colorless. In some stones, the inclusion of small, white, radially clustered crystals of cristobalite in the black glass produce a blotchy or snowflake pattern (snowflake obsidian). It may contain patterns of gas bubbles remaining from the lava flow, aligned along layers created as the molten rock was flowing before being cooled. These bubbles can produce interesting effects such as a golden sheen (sheen obsidian) or a rainbow sheen (rainbow obsidian). [PARAGRAPH:2]Obsidian was valued in Stone Age cultures because, like flint, it could be fractured to produce sharp blades or arrowheads. Like all glass and some other types of naturally occurring rocks, obsidian breaks with a characteristic conchoidal fracture. It was also polished to create early mirrors. Pre-Columbian Mesoamericans' use of obsidian was extensive and sophisticated, including carved and worked obsidian for tools and decorative objects. Mesoamericans also made a type of sword with obsidian blades mounted in a wooden body. Called a macuahuitl, the weapon was capable of inflicting terrible injuries, combining the sharp cutting edge of an obsidian blade with the ragged cut of a serrated weapon. Lithic analysis can be instrumental in understanding prehispanic groups in Mesoamerica. A careful analysis of obsidian in a culture or place can be of use to reconstruct commerce, production, distribution and thereby understand economic, social and political aspects of a civilization. This is the case in Yaxchilán, a maya city where even warfare implications have been studied linked with obsidian use and its debris. [PARAGRAPH:2]Obsidian is used in cardiac surgery, as well-crafted obsidian blades have a cutting edge many times sharper than high-quality steel surgical scalpels, with the edge of the blade being only about 3 nanometres wide. Even the sharpest metal knife has a jagged, irregular blade when viewed under a strong enough microscope. When examined under an electron microscope an obsidian blade is still smooth and even. One study found that obsidian produced narrower scars, fewer inflammatory cells, and less granulation tissue in a group of rats. [PARAGRAPH:2]Obsidian is also used for ornamental purposes and as a gemstone. It possesses the property of presenting a different appearance according to the manner in which it is cut. When cut in one direction it is a beautiful jet black; when cut across another direction it is glistening gray. "Apache tears" are small rounded obsidian nuggets embedded within a grayish-white perlite matrix.

[TAB]Amber is the petrified remnant of ancient tree resins, mostly dating back to the Cretaceous period or later; before that time, evergreen trees did not exist. Amber is rare and prized for its distinctive translucent, typically yellow color, and also for the relative ease with which it can be carved and worked compared to other gem and gem-like materials. It is in effect a semi-precious stone.[PARAGRAPH:2]Amber is found in a variety of sources, although large deposits of this semi-precious stone are rare. Trade in amber flourished in the Baltic sea, chiefly in what is currently the Kaliningrad Oblast of Russia (which still contains 90% of known amber reserves). Certain other deposits exist elsewhere in the world, such as the exotic blue amber of the Dominican Republic.[PARAGRAPH:2]One interesting scientific feature of amber is that, being the fossilized remnant of a sticky organic resin, it can entrap things. There were many cases in the prehistoric past of insects and plant material becoming stuck and "included" inside the resin as it petrified into amber. This has resulted in very well-preserved specimens of flies, mosquitos, and other biological remnants, trapped inside the translucent amber.

[TAB]The cultivation of common millet as the earliest dry crop in East Asia has been attributed to its resistance to drought, and this has been suggested to have aided its spread. Asian varieties of millet made their way from China to the Black Sea region of Europe by 5000 BCE.[PARAGRAPH:2]Millet was growing wild in Greece as early as 3000 BCE, and bulk storage containers for millet have been found from the Late Bronze Age in Macedonia and northern Greece. Hesiod describes that "the beards grow round the millet, which men sow in summer."[25][26] And millet is listed along with wheat in the third century BCE by Theophrastus in his "Enquiry into Plants".[PARAGRAPH:2]Pearl millet is one of the two major crops in the semiarid, impoverished, less fertile agriculture regions of Africa and southeast Asia.[28] Millets are not only adapted to poor, droughty, and infertile soils, but they are also more reliable under these conditions than most other grain crops. This has, in part, made millet production popular, particularly in countries surrounding the Sahara in western Africa.
